newsitem.title: SWEDEN: H&M beats H1 profit estimates, share soars.
newsitem.headline: H&M beats H1 profit estimates, share soars.

text.p: Swedish fashion retailer H&M Hennes & Mauritz put on a show on Monday by presenting a higher than expected pre-tax profit for the first six months of its fiscal year 1996/1997 which sent its share to a record high.
The group said pre-tax profit surged 63 percent to 1.01 billion crowns ($130.1 million) in the first half of its fiscal year while analysts in a Reuter poll targeted 832 million on average.

Shares rocketed 26 crowns to an all-time intra-day high of 293 on the Stockholm Stock Exchange just after the report but slipped back somewhat to trade at 282.5 crowns at 0915 GMT, up 15.5 or six percent.
Profit was boosted by a sales increase of 31 percent to 10.18 billion crowns despite a fairly weak market.
"The general retail sales development in Europe has remained weak, even if some of H&M's markets showed a positive development," the group said.
"The exceptionally favourable sales development...mean that the H&M group have taken relatively large market shares on all markets in the first half year." ($ = 7.763 Swedish Crowns)
The amount of sales outside Sweden edged higher to 78 percent from 74 percent.
Sales rose both in comparable stores -- stores that H&M operated during the first half of 1996/1997 and in the same year-earlier period -- and in new stores, the company said.
H&M opened 21 new stores in the six-month period, compared to 27 in the corresponding previous half year.
"During the remaining part of the fiscal year, H&M plans to open about 35 new stores (up from 32)," it said.
Investments fell to 327 million crowns from 345 million, including a fall in set-up costs to 47 million crowns, from 70 million, the company said.
Operating profit after depreciation rose to 1.01 billion crowns from 646 million, while earnings per share jumped to 3.16 crowns from 1.94.
